content: The Act titled "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 contains findings related to the Act. The Congress finds that improving population health and reducing medical costs requires preventive methods. Organizations in the US need more public health professionals. Only about 6,000 physicians are board certified in preventive medicine. Preventive methods can help avoid costly chronic conditions. The number of preventive medicine programs and students has decreased recently. Preventive medicine is crucial for reducing healthcare costs and avoiding chronic conditions. The number of preventive medicine programs and professionals has decreased, impacting public health. Preventive medicine physicians play a unique role in serving patients and communities, essential for a strong public health system. Loan payment assistance is provided for preventive medicine physicians. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may pay up to $20,000 of medical education loans for eligible preventive medicine physicians who receive board certification in preventive medicine between fiscal years 2008 and 2012. Application for payment must be submitted to the Secretary as required. The Secretary may pay up to $20,000 of medical education loans for eligible preventive medicine physicians who receive board certification in preventive medicine between fiscal years 2008 and 2012. Definitions include eligible physician, medical education loan, and school of medicine. The term "medical education loan" refers to the outstanding principal and interest on a loan for attending a school of medicine. The term "school of medicine" is defined in the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is referred to as the "Secretary." Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out this section. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out this section, with necessary funds authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 4. WELLNESS PROGRAM EMPLOYER CREDIT. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section for a wellness program employer credit. The wellness program employer credit under section 38 allows eligible employers to receive a credit of 25% of expenses for a qualified wellness program, with a maximum of $200 per qualified employee. Eligible employer is defined as an employer who meets certain criteria. The wellness program employer credit under section 38 allows eligible employers to receive a credit of 25% of expenses for a qualified wellness program, with a maximum of $200 per qualified employee. An eligible employer is one who develops and implements a qualified wellness program and keeps accurate records of employee participation in preventive services and other programs. The term 'eligible employer' refers to an employer who develops and implements a qualified wellness program and maintains accurate records of employee participation. A qualified wellness program is one developed and implemented by the employer in consultation with an individual. The term 'qualified wellness program' refers to a program developed and implemented by an eligible employer in consultation with an individual to ensure compliance with privacy measures and conduct health risk assessments for employees. The eligible employer must implement a wellness program that conducts health risk assessments, offers preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, and provides annual counseling sessions. The wellness program must conduct health risk assessments, offer preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, and provide annual counseling sessions and seminars on various topics including smoking, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, and substance abuse. The wellness program must offer seminars on topics such as smoking, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health for qualified participants including at least 50% of the eligible employer's full-time employees. The wellness program must cover topics like smoking, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health for qualified employees, who must make up at least 50% of the eligible employer's full-time staff. Qualified employees for an eligible employer must be full-time employees and qualified participants in the employer's wellness program. Qualified participants are individuals who engage in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs offered by the employer. Qualified participants in an eligible employer's wellness program must engage in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs and undergo a health risk assessment during the taxable year. The section requires qualified participants in an eligible employer's wellness program to undergo a health risk assessment during the taxable year. It does not apply in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012. Conforming amendments are made to Section 38(b) of the Code. The wellness program employer credit determined under section 45O(a) is added to Section 38(b) of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. A new section, "SEC. 25E. WELLNESS PROGRAM PARTICIPANT CREDIT," is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for wellness program participant credit. In the case of a qualified employee, a $200 tax credit is allowed against the tax imposed for the taxable year. A qualified employee is defined as a full-time employee of an eligible employer who is a qualified participant in the employer's wellness program. The term 'qualified employee' refers to a full-time employee of an eligible employer who is a qualified participant in the employer's wellness program. A 'qualified participant' is someone who engages in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs offered by the wellness program and completes a health risk assessment. A 'qualified participant' in a wellness program is an individual who participates in at least 2 annual preventive services and completes a health risk assessment during the taxable year, as determined by the employer. A 'qualified wellness program' is developed and implemented by an eligible employer in consultation with an individual experienced in wellness programs for privacy protection. A 'qualified wellness program' developed by an eligible employer includes health risk assessments and offers preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force. A 'qualified wellness program' for eligible employer participants includes health risk assessments, preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, annual counseling sessions, and seminars on smoking, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, and nutrition. A qualified wellness program must offer annual counseling sessions and seminars on smoking, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health. A qualified wellness program must offer counseling sessions and seminars on various health topics, including nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health. Eligible employers must have at least 50% of full-time employees participating in the program. The text discusses the requirements for an eligible employer to develop and implement a qualified wellness program, including keeping accurate records of employee participation in preventive services. The section will not apply to taxable years after December 31, 2012. The text outlines the requirements for eligible employers to establish a qualified wellness program and maintain records of employee participation in preventive services. This section will no longer apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. The amendment regarding the Wellness program participant credit under Sec. 25E will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007.
